org.spongepowered.api.util.blockray

Class BlockRay.BlockRayBuilder<E extends Extent>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.spongepowered.api.util.blockray.BlockRay.BlockRayBuilder<E>
  • Type Parameters:
    E - The type of the extent for the block ray
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Iterable<BlockRayHit<E>>
    Enclosing class:
    BlockRay<E extends Extent>

    public static class BlockRay.BlockRayBuilder<E extends Extent>
extends Object
implements Iterable<BlockRayHit<E>>
    A builder for block ray, which also implements Iterable, making it useful for 'advanced for loops'. Use BlockRay.from(Location) to get an instance.

      • select

        public final BlockRay.BlockRayBuilder<E> select(Predicate<BlockRayHit<E>> filter)
        Adds a filter to the BlockRay that determines whether a potential BlockRayHit is a valid result, and should therefore be returned by the BlockRay, pausing the ray trace. A ray trace that has been paused due to a BlockRayHit being returned by virtue of this predicate may be continued by calling BlockRay.next() on the associated BlockRay.

        Take care when using this in combination with whilst(Predicate). For any predicate supplied here to match a BlockRayHit, it must also be allowed by any predicates supplied to whilst(Predicate).

        Only one filter may be applied using this method. If a second filter is applied, it will overwrite the first.

        This is optional. If not specified, defaults to BlockRay.allFilter().

        Parameters:
        filter - A filter which determines whether a ray has completed
        Returns:
        This builder, for chaining.
        See Also:
        whilst(Predicate)

      • whilst

        public final BlockRay.BlockRayBuilder<E> whilst(Predicate<BlockRayHit<E>> filter)
        Adds a filter to the BlockRay that determines the conditions upon which a BlockRay may continue to iterate. Such a filter does not cause a BlockRayHit to be returned, instead, it defines the point in which a BlockRay trace should be considered to be at its end and should not attempt to trace further.

        The block ray will continue while the BlockRayHits that are supplied to this Predicate return true. It will end when a BlockRayHit fails the supplied predicate - at which point the iteration will end and no further calls to BlockRay.next() will be possible.

        For example, if you supply the following filter to this method: 

             input -> {
         BlockType type = input.getLocation().getBlockType();
         return type == BlockTypes.AIR || type == BlockTypes.WATER;
     }

        then the BlockRay will trace through air and water, stopping when at the boundary of any other block not matched by the predicate.

        Only one filter may be applied using this method. If a second filter is applied, it will overwrite the first.

        This is optional. If not specified, defaults to BlockRay.allFilter()

        If you wish to cause the ray to return a BlockRayHit, supply a predicate to select(Predicate) instead.

        Parameters:
        filter - The filter to add
        Returns:
        This builder, for chaining.
        See Also:
        select(Predicate)

      • distanceLimit

        public BlockRay.BlockRayBuilder<E> distanceLimit(double distanceLimit)
        Sets the maximum distance before stopping. This is a safeguard to prevent infinite iteration. Default value is 1000. Use a negative value to disable this.
        Parameters:
        distanceLimit - The distance limit
        Returns:
        This for chained calls

      • narrowPhase

        public BlockRay.BlockRayBuilder<E> narrowPhase(boolean enable)
        Sets whether or not to perform narrow phase intersections. The narrow phase performs intersections with the block selection boxes if they are smaller than a voxel. This is necessary to obtain correct intersections with small blocks like: signs, buttons, fences, etc. This is enabled by default.
        Parameters:
        enable - Whether or not to enable the narrow phase
        Returns:
        This for chained calls

      • position

        public com.flowpowered.math.vector.Vector3d position()
        Gets the starting position of the block ray. Given here since some filters might require it.
        Returns:
        The position of the block ray
